title: What will happen if an unauthorized driver totals a rental car under your name, but it is the fault of another driver?
question: I rented a car from National under my University corporate account, which provides full coverage. I let a friend who was not on the rental agreement drive the rental car. She was hit by a drunk driver and the car was totaled and towed away.
answers:
Rental companies are very particular about who drives their cars and who is covered. The insurance you bought will likely not cover the car. Your credit card company might, but not likely, again, because you let someone else drive it.
Your own insurance, if you have any on a vehicle, will also likely not cover it as you were not driving it, unless it is a replacement vehicle while your car was in the shop for a prior accident.
Your friends insurance, if she has it, might cover the damage, if she has collision coverage.
Hopefully the drunk driver has insurance and is enough to cover the damage to the car.
If your friend was injured, she might want to speak with a personal injury attorney.
Both of you should reach out to an attorney and go over everything in detail.
Most of us work throughout the State and work on commission.
Good luck
Kevin
Best to have a lawyer handle this. So not give anyone any statements without first consulting a lawyer.
“What happens” is very vague. Your friend may have her license suspended. You may be out a lot of money if the other driver didn’t have insurance or there’s not some other insurance to cover it.

If you allowed a driver who is not listed on the rental contract as a driver to drive the rental vehicle, neither the rental company nor your auto insurance carrier is going to pay for any damages, as you violated both the rental contract AND your auto insurance policy, which is also a legally binding contract between you and your auto insurer. So, it does not matter that the rental car company "provides full coverage" or if your own auto insurance carrier does as well (actually, there is no such thing as "full coverage," anyway, and people should stop using that term as it is a legal misnomer) as neither of those coverages will apply here.

You and your driver are going to be held responsible for the damages unless the other party's auto insurance carrier accepts liability. If not, the rental car company will be coming after you.

Having said that for your friend's injuries, she should consult with a personal injury attorney in your area. She can use the "Find a lawyer" link at the top of the screen for the names of some personal injury attorneys near her.
